frameDefinitions: The Self_mover, a living being, moves under its own direction along a Path.
A Speaker uses a particular linguistic form, a Name to refer to an Entity.
In this frame a Fluid moves from a Source to a Goal along a Path or within an Area.  '
An Agent or a Cause causes a Fluid to move from a Source to a Goal along a Path or within an Area.
A Mass_theme, generally made up of many individuals, moves from a Source to a Goal with some Path.
Water in some solid or liquid form (the Precipitation) falls from the sky at a particular Place and Time, lasting for a particular Duration.
frameExamples: She <t>walked</t> along the road for a while.
They corresponded frequently and at length, exchanging intimate letters in which he <t>addressed</t> her as Windflower.
Emails from so-called Nigerian princes <t>flooded</t> inboxes all over the US.
listRoleDefinitions: <fen>Self_mover</fen> is the living being which moves under its own power. Normally it is expressed as an external argument.

<fen>Source</fen> is used for any expression which implies a definite starting-point of motion.
In prepositional phrases, the prepositional object expresses the starting point of motion.  With particles, the starting point of motion is understood from context.
<fen>Path</fen> is used for any description of a trajectory of motion which is neither a <fen>Source</fen> nor a <fen>Goal</fen>.  This includes 'middle of path'' expressions.
<fen>Goal</fen> is used for any expression which tells where the <fen>Self_mover</fen> ends up as a result of the motion.

<fen>Area</fen> is used for expressions which describe a general area in which motion takes place when the motion is understood to be irregular and not to consist of a single linear path.  Note that this role should not be used for cases when the same phrase could be used with the same meaning with a non-motion target, since these should be annotated with the <fen>Place</fen> FE.
The direction that the <fen>Self_mover</fen> heads in during the motion.
The time when the motion occurs.

The <fen>Place</fen> is the location within which a defined motion takes place.  Any specified or implied  <fen>Source</fen>, <fen>Path</fen> or <fen>Goal</fen> should designate a location contained with the <fen>Place</fen>.  This role can be differentiated from <fen>Area</fen> by the fact that the annotated phrase can be used in the same meaning with non-motion targets.
The person who uses the <fen>Name</fen>  to refer to the <fen>Entity</fen>.
The entity that is designated by the <fen>Speaker</fen> with the <fen>Name</fen> used.
The linguistic form used by the <fen>Speaker</fen> to refer to the <fen>Entity</fen>.
The point of time or interval when the <fen>Speaker</fen> uses the <fen>Name</fen>.
<fen>Area</fen> is the setting in which the <fen>Fluid</fen>'s movement takes place on an unspecified <fen>Path</fen>.
<fen>Goal</fen> is the location the <fen>Fluid</fen> ends up.
The <fen>Path</fen> is the trajectory along which the <fen>Fluid</fen> moves.
The <fen>Source</fen> is the location the <fen>Fluid</fen> occupies initially.
The <fen>Fluid</fen> is the entity that changes location and moves in a fluidic way.
The <fen>Time</fen> when the <fen>Fluid</fen> flows.
The Place describes the location of the motion which has a specified Source, Path or Goal.
The animate protagonist who causes the <fen>Fluid</fen> to move.
An event or force that causes the <fen>Fluid</fen> to move.
The entity that changes location and moves in a fluidic way. It is not necessarily in a liquid state but is construed that way.
The location that the <fen>Fluid</fen> occupies initially.
<fen>Goal</fen> is the location the <fen>Fluid</fen> ends up in as a result  of the motion
The trajectory along which the Fluid moves, exclusive of the <fen>Source</fen> and <fen>Goal</fen>.
The setting in which the <fen>Fluid</fen>'s movement takes place along an unspecified <fen>Path</fen>.
The <fen>Time</fen> when the fluidic motion event is caused.
The location where the motion takes place.
The mass of entities which moves.
The place where the overall motion event takes place, thus including Source, Path, and Goal locations.
The Source is the location the Theme occupies initially before its change of location.
Path refers to (a part of the) ground the <fen>Mass_theme</fen> travels over or to a landmark the <fen>Mass_theme</fen> travels by.
Goal is the location the <fen>Mass_theme</fen> ends up in.

This role is used for expressions that indicate motion along a line from the deitic center towards a reference point (which may be implicit) that is neither the <fen>Goal</fen> of the posture change nor a landmark along the way of the moving part of the body.  Often <fen>Direction</fen> is defined with reference to the canonical orientation of the <fen>Mass_theme</fen>, or the orientation imposed by an implicit observer.
When the event occurs.
The spatial setting in which the Mass_motion takes place.
The water in liquid or solid form that falls from the sky is the Precipitation. This role is incorporated in many LUs in this frame.
The area which experiences precipitation.
When the event occurs.
listRoleExamples: <fex>Fred</fex> crawled the narrow passage.
The cat ran <fex>out of the house</fex>.
The scouts hiked <fex>through the desert</fex>.
The children skipped <fex>into the park</fex>.
The mouse scurried <fex>about</fex>.
You should walk <fex>south</fex> about a block .
The hitchhikers walked <fex>in the middle of the road</fex>.
<fex>The Lord, who was charmed by her beauty,</fex> addressed her as 'than kaadhali!' (My darling) and hence the name.
And that's the reason why we called <fex>him</fex> 'Tom' when his real name was actually John.
A male voice answered the call, and Jones addressed the man as <fex>'Johnny.'</fex>
No one had <fex>ever</fex> called her 'my lady'.
The Thames River flows <fex>throughout England</fex>.
<fex>At Oregon Caves</fex>, a stream runs through the dining room.
What happens if <fex>we</fex> drip acid on this compound?
Why did  you squirt juice <fex>onto my chair</fex>?
I splattered red paint <fex> nearby</fex>.
I spattered the egg all over the floor <fex>in the kitchen</fex>.
Letters streamed in <fex>all over the country</fex>.
Afterwards, the crowd flooded <fex>away from the ceremony</fex>.
The door opened , and a crowd of people flooded <fex>past me</fex>, into the hall.
Eager spectators crowded <fex>into the auditorium</fex>
<fex>In the main auditorium</fex> people crowded around Orange's newest computer
It will probably be raining <fex>at five o'clock</fex>.

sourceCandidateSpans.text: the Department of Public Works and Highways (DPWH)
